abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for St. Vincent and the
            Grenadines emergency recovery and disaster management
            project were as follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial and the Bank and borrower performance
            was satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project:
            Harnessing the trust and ownership of local communities is
            essential to successfully undertake major mitigation works.
            In the case of this project, the early involvement of the
            disaster agency (NEMO) in building community awareness and
            informing the local population of the purpose and benefits
            of major mitigation works was a key factor to achieving a
            positive outcome of the project. When a project is put in
            abeyance during preparation and subsequently re-activated on
            a fast track processing schedule, the Bank needs to pay
            closer attention to the revision of design and cost
            estimates for major civil works. When faced with critical
            shortage of technical expertise as it was the case for major
            civil works with the Ministry of Works, the Government
            should consider more systematic recruitment of outside
            expertise. The Bank needs to consider requiring performance
            guarantees in consultant contracts and applying penalties
            for late submission of expected outputs.
